title: Google TV on the Enterprise
comment: The app works as advertised for hooking up to an enterprise system.  The only problem I have is that trying to edit any networks in the settings results in crashes.  If you try to switch networks, it seems to let you do it once, but then the entire settings app crashes and so far the only way that we have found to fix it is to do a complete factory reset.  With a couple of tweaks this could be the best app I have ever had on an android device.  It would also be awesome if you could add proxy settings in for networks, esp User/Pass@domain:port style.

title: Never Updated

This app has not been updated in more than year, and the developer does not seem very receptive to writing this app for ICS devices and above, even though their prevalence has skyrocketed.

title: Beware! Crashed my phone
comment: This app crashed my phone. I edited a wireless config, and then the app crashed. After that, the normal wifi settings page would hang on load, USB didn't work to back up. All I could do was a factory reset, with no chance to save un-backed up data.  When I re-installed, the problem wifi config seemed to work, so I guess it fixed my problem in a roundabout way...
Fantastic. Can connect to WEP now.

comment: Simple, effective, and useful. User interface not user friendly.

title: Very useful app
comment: This app is very useful if you want to hook up to a hidden network, which needs network configurations. It is very simple to use, but finding out the correct wifi configuration might be challenging esp when the IT department do not help.

title: Nice but danger
comment: This application show the Wi-Fi configuration, but for some reason got the phone into reset cycle (constant resets).  Only solution was to disable the Wi-Fi then go back to factory reset.

Resetting the phone does not help, only option i had was to re-install firmware. i did that, and again when i installed this software same happened. Phone hangs in settings, wifi could not be disabled.

title: Genius!
comment: Overcomes a shortcoming in Gingerbread (and maybe other versions) in which you can not edit WPA2 Enterprise passwords (that I could find). Workaround was to Forget and re-add the network, which means lots of typing each time a password change is required (by corporate policy). This works perfectly and has a miniscule footprint (<100k). Should be built in. Get it if you need to connect to WPA2 Enterprise networks.
